p.s: The use of narrative techniques, in this excerpt, shows the reader the inner conflict in DelaneysDelaney's mind and his further development into a racist.
The narrator is a limited third-person narrator who, in this excerpt shows Delaney's point of view.
This, of course, helps the reader understand DelaneysDelaney's thought process while still having some distance allowing the narrator to comment.
This distance allows the reader to judge the current character who's point of view it is and prevents the reader from fully empathizing with them.
To show the inner conflict going on in Delaney, between his liberal-humanist ideals and his racist-tendenciesracist tendencies a lot of rhetorical questions are used.
In the beginning (ll. 1f) a rhetorical question is used to show Delaney's inner rebellion against the gate and unwillingnesunwillingness for starting conflicts.
However, the further use of rethoricalrhetorical questions, is to show his racist-tendenciesracist tendencies (ll. 25f, 35f).
Those questions show inner accusations, made by him, at the mexican Jos√©.
He almost characterises him as a criminal, thinking of him to bother his wife and maybe break in a house.

At the beginning of the last paragraph (ll. 60f) a rethoricalrhetorical question is used to show Delaney questioning his current behaviour and morals, seeing as though it doesn't fit his self-image of a self-proclaimed liberal-humanist but rather the opposite.
This meaning, DelaneysDelaney's development into a racist is still not far, he is still feeling regret and guilt and he seems to fear what he could become.
In this excerpt, specifically the first 6 paragraphs, Delaney's rage for the mexicanMexican is shown through climatic-kindclimatic kind of structures.
The first structure (l. 7) underlines him only focusing on the car and his obsession with it.
The next climatic-structureclimatic structure shows the way Delaney almost arranging happenings to fit his image of immigrants.
This time (l. 19) it makes the mexicanMexican look more like a criminal than he in that moment is.
Also (l. 48) Delaney is getting more and more enraged by persuading himself that his current situation is important and how respectless the mexicanMexican is (l. 31, 33f, 40f, 48).
He practically makes himself feel less than he is and making him wanting to proof that he's able to defend his neighborhood.
This could relate to him not wanting a gate and trying to show himself that he can protect himself and that the outside-worldoutside world is not a dangerous as he thinks it is (ll. 56f).
Although the reader is able to see him feeling unsure of himself wishing for other people's help (l. 52f).
Through making himself ready for a fight and more enraged, the realisation of him being wrong and becoming the opposite of what he thinks himself to be, hits him hard.
This has the effect of him only doubting himself even more.
